Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant qualifies as a Convention refugee under s. 2(3) of the Immigration Act due to past persecution
Application_Facts: The applicant was tortured by MQM in 1989
Board doubted credibility but acknowledged severe past persecution
Decision_Outcome: Board erred in requiring ongoing fear of persecution
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Court_Ruling: Application allowed, case remanded for a new hearing with a differently constituted tribunal
Grounds_for_Claim: Past persecution including torture and destruction of property
Legal_Standard: Section 2(3) applies if the claimant suffered atrocious acts of persecution, has subjective fear, and suffers continuing psychological effects
Procedural_Issue: Remand for new hearing due to error in legal interpretation
Review_Standard: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)
Credibility_Assessment: Board expressed doubts about applicant's credibility
Application_Basis: Claim of past persecution meeting threshold of atrocious acts under s. 2(3)
Evidence_Assessed: Personal testimony regarding torture and persecution
Governing_Rule: Section 2(3) of the Immigration Act requires atrocious acts, subjective fear, and continuing psychological effects
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Perceived lack of credible evidence supporting ongoing fear
Outcome: Application allowed; remanded for new hearing
Harm_Assessment: Severe physical and psychological harm from torture and persecution
Cause_Description: Applicant's claim for refugee status was denied by the Board, leading to judicial review
Evidence_Handling: Board assessed credibility and weight of personal testimony
Legal_Provision_Violated: None found; issue was misapplication of s. 2(3) standard
Evidence_Assessment: Testimonial evidence considered but credibility questioned
Decision_Rationale: Error in requiring ongoing fear; focus should be on severity of past persecution under s. 2(3)
